title: 108_s474
content: The Act titled "American 5-Cent Coin Design Continuity Act of 2003" establishes designs on the 5-cent coin. The Secretary of the Treasury may change the design of the 5-cent coin for 2003-2005 to commemorate the Louisiana Purchase and Lewis and Clark expedition, depicting a new likeness of President Thomas Jefferson on the obverse. The Secretary of the Treasury may change the reverse design of the 5-cent coins issued during 2003-2005 to depict images related to the Louisiana Purchase or the expedition of Meriwether Lewis and William Clark. The coins must also meet all other requirements for inscriptions and designations under section 5112(d)(1) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 102 amends the design of the 5-cent coin to feature Thomas Jefferson on the obverse and his home at Monticello on the reverse. The Secretary must consult with advisory committees for the design. The Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee is established to advise the Secretary of the Treasury on coin themes and designs. It consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary. The Advisory Committee consists of 3 members appointed based on their expertise in numismatic collections, medallic arts, or sculpture. The Advisory Committee consists of members appointed based on their expertise in American history, numismatics, and representing the general public's interests in US coinage. Additionally, 4 persons are appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from officials. The Advisory Committee members are selected based on their expertise in American history and numismatics. Recommendations for appointment are made by officials, including the Speaker of the House, minority and majority leaders of the House and Senate. Members serve a 4-year term. The Advisory Committee members are appointed for 4-year terms, with initial appointees serving varying term lengths. No individual currently serving in the Federal Government can be appointed to the Committee. The Advisory Committee members serve for 4-year terms, with initial appointees having varying term lengths. Appointed members can continue to serve for up to 6 months after their term expires until a successor is appointed. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members can be removed at the discretion of the Secretary. The Chairperson is appointed for a 1-year term from among the Committee members by the Secretary. The Advisory Committee members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. They must meet at least twice annually as called by the Secretary, chairperson, or majority of members. The Advisory Committee meets twice annually and each meeting is open to the public. Timely notice of meetings is published in the Federal Register and trade publications. A quorum consists of 7 members. The Committee advises the Secretary of the Treasury on coinage and medal designs. The Advisory Committee advises the Secretary of the Treasury on the issuance of commemorative coins, including recommending events, persons, or places to be commemorated, mintage levels, and proposed designs. Expenses of the Committee are paid from the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. The Advisory Committee receives administrative support, technical services, and advice from the Director of the United States Mint as needed. They may consult with the Commission of Fine Arts and are required to submit an annual report to the Secretary and the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives by September 30 each year. The Advisory Committee on coinage activities must submit an annual report to the Secretary of the Treasury and relevant congressional committees by September 30 each year. The report should detail the Committee's activities and recommendations made to the Secretary. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to this Committee. The Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee is abolished, and its members can continue to serve their terms. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to this Committee. The Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee is abolished, and its members may continue to serve on the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee in designated positions. Technical and conforming amendments are made to relevant sections of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 201. CLARIFICATION OF EXISTING LAW. Payment of surcharges on numismatic items must only be made to designated recipient organizations after all operation costs have been recovered and an audited financial statement is submitted. The organization must raise funds equal to or greater than the proceeds from surcharges on numismatic items before receiving unpaid amounts from the fund. The organization must raise funds equal to or greater than the proceeds from surcharges on numismatic items within a 2-year period. Any unpaid amounts after this period will be deposited in the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts. The amendment applies as of the date of the enactment of Public Law 104-208.
